monogr.author: Richard Maurice Bucke
monogr.title: The Letters of Dr. Richard Maurice Bucke to Walt Whitman

bibl.author: Richard Maurice Bucke
bibl.title: Richard Maurice Bucke to Walt Whitman, 6 November 1891
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Whitman used the verso of this letter from Bucke to write his November 9–10, 1891, letter to Dr. John Johnston.

body.p: Your letter of 3d inst. came last evening and was heartily welcomed. [—] Many thanks also for the Press of 3d containing "A Poets Greeting to a Poet." /fishy-fish enough / [—] I wish I could have been there and assisted in the good talk. [—] So Wallace has gone—I guess he will live a long time before he forgets his visit to America—I am rejoiced that he came so that we could have the chance of showing him a little attention in return to the the many kindnesses he has done us. He is a splendid fellow and I trust I may often see him and the other good Bolton fellows before I finish my earthly pilgrimage—such chaps as they are make the world worth living in. All quiet here and nothing new. I have a 2 hour lecture tomorrow morning and have just been hard at work preparing it. I wish you had some of my physical strength, dear Walt, so that Major Pond might take you on the lecture platform—but I fear that cannot be—worse luck!
